ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to talk about movies in Chinese and some specific vocabulary/sentence structures related to the texts we had.
I learned quite a lot of vocabulary, and my ability to read stories definitely improved.
Correct pronunciations/ intonations of Chinese words, how to phrase in a more natural way, etc

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really like how this class had very few examinations but a lot of active learning through discussions, reading short stories, presentations, and watching movies. I really felt like I was learning Chinese in a passive but engaging way.

I think this course is well-structured for people who want to learn more specific chinese vocabularly, but the study guides for each unit were too long to learn comprehensively (and we mainly had to learn them in our own time). However, I liked the small class sizes and how we were encouraged to talk about our own opinions on larger questions in class. The examinations are homework were also pretty straightforward.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it's so much more chill than the lower level Chinese classes and it really feels like you get rewarded for sticking with Chinese for so long

Yes, it's a more care-free enviroment (relative to beginner Chinese classes) to improve on Chinese skills. I looked forward to class every week but wish I could've interacted with my peers more. Most of the discussion was directed to the professor.
